comments.body: So do we run the risk here that pip has it's own pinned resolvelib version but we have another or does pip vendor it entirely and we don't care about it?
It's one of the libs pip re-vendors every once in a while: https://github.com/pypa/pip/tree/master/src/pip/_vendor#vendoring-policy. For example: https://github.com/pypa/pip/pull/9369.
So I'd say we don't care. We'll need to upgrade the upper bound once in a while along with updating our code to work with newer public API when necessary.
Not entirely correct.... Linux distros typically unvendor libraries.  So you could still end up with a problem if you pin your versions too strictly.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +11,15 @@# NOTE: and we should update the upper cap with care, at least until 1.0
# NOTE: Ref: https://github.com/sarugaku/resolvelib/issues/69
resolvelib >= 0.5.3, < 0.6.0  # dependency resolver used by ansible-galaxy
